title: At Chevalier Theatre, Mavis Staples lives up to her legacy of joy and protest
author: Terence Cawley
bullets: Mavis Staples performed at Chevalier Theatre, showcasing her deep, recognizable voice and blending gospel-soul roots with modern Americana.
At 86, Staples maintained her protest-singer spirit with songs addressing current events and advocating for civil rights.
The 12-song set included Staples Singers classics and covers, finishing with an uplifting rendition of 'Everybody Needs Love.'

title: Here’s how the Red Sox plan on handling MLB’s new ABS challenging system
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: The Boston Red Sox plan to utilize MLB's new ABS challenge system for balls and strikes actively in 2026.
Under new rules, each team receives two challenges per game, retaining them if successful, allowing unlimited uses until losing twice.
Red Sox manager Alex Cora encourages embracing challenges; players like Nate Eaton have prior ABS experience from Triple-A.

title: Red Sox ace Garrett Crochet weighs in on Lucas Giolito’s ongoing free agency
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: Lucas Giolito remains unsigned in free agency after opting out of his Red Sox contract following a strong 2025 season.
Garrett Crochet expresses surprise at Giolito's free agent status, noting his impressive performance in the 2025 season.
Red Sox added Sonny Gray and Ranger Suarez to their rotation, reducing the likelihood of re-signing Giolito.

title: 5 possible trade targets for Patriots outside of Maxx Crosby, A.J. Brown
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots consider trading for Colts WR Michael Pittman Jr., who may face release due to cap concerns.
Bears WR DJ Moore, rumored as a trade candidate, logged 50 receptions for 682 yards last season.
Seattle's Uchenna Nwosu, with 7 sacks in the last season, is a potential trade target for the Patriots.

title: Jayson Tatum says he still doesn’t have a return date after participating in a 5-on-5 scrimmage at Celtics practice
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Jayson Tatum participated in a five-on-five scrimmage but says he has no set return date from his Achilles injury.
Photos of Tatum practicing sparked speculation of an imminent return, but the Celtics haven't confirmed any timetable.
Tatum is rehabbing after a season-long absence, with coach Joe Mazzulla emphasizing the goal of achieving 100% health.

title: NBC Sports broadcast teams rise to the occasion with Olympic calls from Milan Cortina
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Kenny Albert and A.J. Mleczko praised for their call during Team USA's women's hockey gold medal win over Canada.
Terry Gannon, Tara Lipinski, and Johnny Weir allowed silence to highlight Alysa Liu's gold-medal figure skating performance.
Providence ranked first in viewership ratings for the Patriots' Super Bowl loss to the Seahawks, with Boston placing third.

title: Free MBTA bus program extended â€” for now
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Boston extends free rides on MBTA bus routes 23, 28, and 29 through June using remaining federal funds.
The four-year pilot was initially funded by $8 million in federal pandemic relief, reimbursing the MBTA $340,000 monthly.
Mayor Michelle Wu and MBTA officials are discussing future funding options beyond June for the fare-free program.

title: Snow totals: See how much snow your town got
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Franklin County reported the highest snow totals with 6.5 inches in Leyden on Saturday morning.
Essex County saw significant snowfall with Haverhill receiving up to 5 inches.
A high impact storm is expected Sunday night into Monday, with blizzard conditions and power outages possible.

title: She’s running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the 2013 bombing victims
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Marissa LaRosa, 30, from Canton, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to honor the 2013 bombing victims.
LaRosa cites personal inspiration from her coworker Annie, who has run the Boston Marathon 24 times.
The April 20, 2026 race will be an emotionally significant event for LaRosa, honoring the victims and herself.

title: NH man sentenced for using $1M in COVID relief funds to buy golf course
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Michael Kirouac of Pembroke, NH, sentenced to 15 months in prison for fraudulently securing over $1M in COVID relief.
Kirouac used $600,000 of the relief funds to purchase the Angus Lea Golf Course in Hillsborough, prosecutors said.
He obtained loans intended for small businesses, pled guilty to wire fraud, and will have one year of supervised release.
